hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
Linear algebra provides the language and tools for representing and solving
systems of equations, analyzing economic models, and studying optimization
problems. This chapter introduces the basic objects and operations that will
be used throughout the rest of these notes.

The emphasis is on intuition, structure, and economic relevance,
rather than formal proofs.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
A scalar is a single number, such as income, price, or an interest rate.

A vector is an ordered collection of numbers. For example, a vector of
outputs from different sectors can be written asx =
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2 \\
\vdots \\
x_n
\end{bmatrix}.

A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers. For example,A =
\begin{bmatrix}
a_{11} & a_{12} \\
a_{21} & a_{22}
\end{bmatrix}.

Matrices are used to represent:

systems of linear equations,

technological relationships,

linear transformations.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
Two matrices of the same dimension can be added element by element:A + B = [a_{ij} + b_{ij}].

A matrix can be multiplied by a scalar c:cA = [c a_{ij}].

These operations behave much like addition and multiplication of numbers.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
Matrix multiplication is defined so that dimensions must be compatible.
If A is an m \times n matrix and B is an n \times k matrix, then
AB is an m \times k matrix.

The (i,j) element of AB is given by(AB)_{ij} = \sum_{k} a_{ik} b_{kj}.

Matrix multiplication is not commutative in general:AB \neq BA.

This non-commutativity is economically important: the order of
transformations matters.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
The transpose of a matrix A, denoted A', is obtained by swapping rows
and columns:(A')_{ij} = a_{ji}.

For example,A =
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 \\
3 & 4
\end{bmatrix},
\qquad
A' =
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 3 \\
2 & 4
\end{bmatrix}.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
A matrix is symmetric ifA = A'.

Symmetric matrices arise naturally in:

quadratic forms,

Hessian matrices,

second-order conditions in optimization.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
The identity matrix I satisfiesAI = IA = A.

For example,I =
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}.

The zero matrix has all elements equal to zero and acts as the additive
identity.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
A square matrix A is invertible if there exists a matrix A^{-1} such
thatAA^{-1} = A^{-1}A = I.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
If Ax = b, then multiplying both sides by A^{-1} yieldsx = A^{-1} b.

Thus, the inverse matrix allows us to solve systems of linear equations.

Not all matrices are invertible. Non-invertibility typically reflects:

redundancy,

linear dependence,

the absence of a unique solution.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
The determinant of a square matrix is a scalar value that summarizes key
properties of the matrix.

For a 2 \times 2 matrix,A =
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix},

the determinant is given by\det(A) = ad - bc.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
If \det(A) = 0, the matrix is singular (not invertible).

If \det(A) \neq 0, the matrix is invertible.

The determinant reflects the volume-scaling effect of a linear
transformation.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
Cramer’s Rule provides an explicit solution to a system of linear equationsAx = b,

when A is invertible.

For each component x_i, the solution isx_i = \frac{\det(A_i)}{\det(A)},

where A_i is obtained by replacing the i-th column of A with b.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
Cramer’s Rule is mainly of theoretical interest.

It shows how solutions depend on determinants.

It is inefficient for large systems but conceptually illuminating.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
The columns of a matrix are linearly dependent if one column can be
expressed as a linear combination of the others.

Linear dependence implies:

loss of information,

non-invertibility,

multiple or no solutions.

The rank of a matrix measures the number of linearly independent rows or
columns.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
hierarchy.lvl2: Why Linear Algebra Matters in Economics

records.content:
Linear algebra underpins:

equilibrium analysis,

comparative statics,

input–output models,

optimization problems,

dynamic systems.

Later chapters will show how these basic tools are used to analyze:

stability,

convexity,

optimality conditions.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts
Linear Algebra: Basic Concepts

records.content:
In the next chapter, we extend these ideas to special matrices that play a
central role in optimization and economic modeling, including:

Jacobian matrices,

Hessian matrices,

quadratic forms and definiteness.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
This chapter introduces special matrices that play a central role in
optimization, comparative statics, and economic modeling. These matrices
summarize how systems respond to changes and how curvature determines
optimality.

The focus is on interpretation and application, rather than abstract
theory.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Consider a vector-valued functionf(x) =
\begin{bmatrix}
f_1(x_1,\dots,x_n) \\
\vdots \\
f_m(x_1,\dots,x_n)
\end{bmatrix}.

The Jacobian matrix of f is the matrix of first-order partial derivatives:J(x) =
\begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_1}{\partial x_n} \\
\vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\frac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_1} & \cdots & \frac{\partial f_m}{\partial x_n}
\end{bmatrix}.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Each row describes how one equation responds to changes in the variables.

The Jacobian generalizes the derivative to multivariate settings.

In economics, Jacobians appear in:

systems of equations,

equilibrium conditions,

comparative statics.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Under mild regularity conditions, the Hessian is symmetric.

The Hessian summarizes the curvature of a function.

It plays a central role in second-order conditions for optimization.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Given a symmetric matrix A and a vector x, the expressionx' A x

is called a quadratic form.

Quadratic forms arise naturally when:

approximating functions locally,

analyzing curvature,

studying stability.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
IfA =
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
b & c
\end{bmatrix},
\qquad
x =
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2
\end{bmatrix},

thenx'Ax = a x_1^2 + 2b x_1 x_2 + c x_2^2.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
A symmetric matrix A is:

positive definite if x'Ax > 0 for all x \neq 0,

negative definite if x'Ax < 0 for all x \neq 0,

indefinite if x'Ax takes both positive and negative values.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Positive definiteness corresponds to convexity.

Negative definiteness corresponds to concavity.

These properties determine whether a critical point is a minimum or a maximum.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
hierarchy.lvl2: Principal Minors and the Determinant Test

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
hierarchy.lvl2: Principal Minors and the Determinant Test

records.content: For a symmetric matrix, definiteness can be checked using principal minors.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
hierarchy.lvl2: Principal Minors and the Determinant Test

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
hierarchy.lvl2: Principal Minors and the Determinant Test

records.content:
LetA =
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
b & c
\end{bmatrix}.

The matrix A is positive definite ifa > 0,
\qquad
\det(A) = ac - b^2 > 0.

This test is especially useful in applied work, where computing symbolic
eigenvalues may be inconvenient.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
An alternative characterization of definiteness uses eigenvalues.

A symmetric matrix is:

positive definite if all eigenvalues are positive,

negative definite if all eigenvalues are negative.

Eigenvalues provide geometric intuition: they describe how a quadratic form
stretches space along its principal directions.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
When optimizing a function subject to constraints, the bordered Hessian
is used to check second-order conditions.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
For a problem with one constraint, the bordered Hessian takes the formH_B =
\begin{bmatrix}
0 & g_x' \\
g_x & H
\end{bmatrix},

where:

g_x is the gradient of the constraint,

H is the Hessian of the Lagrangian.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
The bordered Hessian incorporates both curvature and constraints.

The sign pattern of its principal minors determines optimality.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Linear algebra is central to input–output analysis.

Let A denote the matrix of technical coefficients, and let x denote output.
The systemx = Ax + d

can be rewritten as(I - A)x = d.

If (I - A) is invertible, the solution isx = (I - A)^{-1} d.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
(I - A)^{-1} is the Leontief inverse.

It captures both direct and indirect production requirements.

Invertibility reflects feasibility and stability of the production system.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
Special matrices allow us to:

characterize equilibrium behavior,

determine optimality,

analyze stability,

understand economic structure.

They form the mathematical backbone of:

constrained optimization,

dynamic systems,

general equilibrium models.

hierarchy.lvl1: Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications
Linear Algebra: Special Matrices and Applications

records.content:
With these tools in place, we are ready to move beyond linear algebra and
introduce calculus-based methods, beginning with multivariate calculus
and optimization.
